noteParagraph.text: Alkali metals: Li, Na, K, Rb, Cs, Fr
Alkaline earth metals: Ca, Sr, Ba, Ra
Lanthanides: elements with atomic numbers 57 to 71 inclusive
Actinides: elements with atomic numbers 89 to 103 inclusive
Refractory metals: Ti, V, Cr, Zr, Nb, Mo, Hf, Ta, W
Halogens: F, Cl, Br, I, At
Noble gases: He, Ne, Ar, Kr, Xe, Rn
Platinum group: Os, Ir, Pt, Ru, Rh, Pd
Noble metals: Ag, Au, Platinum group
Light metals: alkali metals, alkaline earth metals, Be, Al, Mg
Heavy metals: metals other than light metals
Non-metals: H, B, C, Si, N, P, O, S, Se, Te, noble gases, halogens
Transition elements: elements with atomic numbers 21 to 30 inclusive, 39 to 48 inclusive, 57 to 80 inclusive, 89 upwards

titlePart.text: Furnaces so far as specially adapted for glass manufacture
by passing an electric current between electrodes immersed in the glass bath, i.e. by direct resistance heating
by using resistance heaters above or in the glass bath, i. e. by indirect resistance heating
in combined tank furnaces and pots
Special features of the melting process
Auxiliary means specially adapted for glass-melting furnaces
Bridges, shoes, throats, or other devices for withholding dirt, foam, or batch
Details of construction of furnace walls, e.g. to prevent corrosion
Use of materials for furnace walls
Means for taking-off charges of molten glass
Means for thermal conditioning or controlling the temperature of the glass
Cutting-off the glass flow with the aid of knives or scissors
Transferring molten glass or gobs to glass blowing or pressing machines
Gathering-devices in the form of rods or pipes
Making hollow glass articles with feet or projections
Making hollow glass articles with double walls, e.g. vacuum flasks
Finish-blowing with compressed air of blanks blown with the mouth
Blowing glass cylinders for sheet manufacture
starting from a ribbon of glass
in machines of the endless-chain type
Use of materials for the moulds
Giving special shapes to parts of hollow glass articles
Forming screw threads or lips at the mouth of hollow glass articles
Making hollow glass articles with feet or projections
Forming bottoms to blown hollow glass articles
Glass-blowing moulds not otherwise provided for
Construction of the blank or blow mould
Supplying, ejecting, or controlling the air
Means for cooling, heating, or insulating glass-blowing machines
Gearing or controlling mechanisms specially adapted for glass-blowing machines
Means for fusing, burning-off, or edge-melting combined with glass-blowing machines
Means for discharging combined with glass-blowing machines, e.g. take-outs
Means for cutting the hot glass in glass-blowing machines
Use of materials for the moulds
in machines with moulds fed by suction
for making solid articles, e.g. lenses
Cooling, heating, or insulating the plunger, the mould, or the glass-pressing machine
Gearing or controlling mechanisms specially adapted for glass presses
Rolling glass with enclosures, e.g. wire or asbestos
Auxiliary means for rolling glass, e.g. sheet supports, gripping devices, hand-ladles, means for moving glass pots
Drawing glass upwardly from the melt
from the free surface of the melt
by means of bars below the surface of the melt
multi-layer glass sheets or glass sheets coated with coloured layers
Drawing tubes, cylinders, or rods from the melt
Drawing tubes, cylinders, or rods, coated with coloured layers
Means for laying-down and conveying combined with the drawing of glass sheets, tubes, or rods
Forming glass by flowing out, pushing-out, or drawing downwardly or laterally from forming slits or by overflowing over lips
Forming glass coated with coloured layers
Forming tubes or rods by drawing from stationary or rotating tools or from forming nozzles
Shaping glass in contact with the surface of a liquid
Changing or regulating the dimensions of the molten glass ribbon
using mechanical means, e.g. restrictor bars, edge rollers
Making multilayer, coloured or armoured glass
Changing the surface of the glass ribbon, e.g. roughening
Use of material for the float tank
Coating or protection of the tank wall
Controlling or regulating the temperature of the float bath
Composition or purification of the float bath
Composition of the atmosphere above the float bath
Treating or purifying the atmosphere above the float bath
Controlling or regulating the temperature of the atmosphere above the float tank

titlePart.entryReference: production of quartz or fused silica articles

titlePart.text: by fusing powdered glass in a shaping mould
Processes specially adapted for the production of quartz or fused silica articles
Severing glass sheets, tubes, or rods while still plastic
with moulds having at least two upward pivotable mould sections
in a continuous way, e.g. roll forming
using a gas cushion or by changing gas pressure, e.g. by applying vacuum
by blowing, e.g. for making electric bulbs
Reshaping the ends, e.g. as grooves, threads or mouths
Reshaping by drawing without blowing, in combination with separating, e.g. for making ampoules
Reshaping combined with uniting or heat sealing, e.g. making vacuum bottles
Uniting glass pieces by fusing without substantial reshaping
Uniting glass rods, glass tubes, or hollow glassware
for the production of cathode ray tubes or similarly shaped tubes
Uniting glass lenses, e.g. forming bifocal lenses
Making hollow glass sheets or bricks
with horizontal displacement of the glass products
with vertical displacement of the glass products
using liquid, e.g. molten metal or salt
for glass products other than flat or bent glass plates, e.g. hollow glassware, lenses
Reheating glass products for softening or fusing their surfaces
Manufacture of rippled or crackled glass
Thermal after-treatment of glass products not provided for in groups , e.g. crystallisation, eliminating gas inclusions or other impurities
Cutting or splitting in curves, especially for making spectacle lenses
Cutting or splitting glass tubes, rods, or hollow products
Cutting armoured or laminated glass products
Transporting of glass products during their manufacture
Transporting of hot hollow glass products
Feeding of hot hollow glass products into annealing or heating kilns
using rotary means directly acting on the products
using reciprocating means directly acting on the products, e.g. pushers, stackers
by gripping tongs or supporting frames
on a fluid support bed, e.g. on molten metal
Transporting of glass tubes or rods
Manufacture or treatment of flakes, fibres, or filaments from softened glass, minerals, or slags
Manufacture of glass fibres or filaments
of tubes, rods, fibres or filaments
having means for deflecting or stripping-off fibres
by projecting on a rotating body having no radial orifices
by blasting or blowing molten glass, e.g. for making staple fibres
starting from tubes, rods, fibres, or filaments
Fibres or filaments characterised by their shape or composition, e.g. hollow fibres, ondulated fibres, fibres of different sorts of glass
of fibres or filaments during winding up
Preventing adhesion between glass and glass or between glass and the means used to shape it
Use of materials as release or lubricating compositions
